Waste Management and Resource Recovery Association
Acknowledgement
of Country
The Waste Management and Resource Recovery Association of
Australia (WMRR) acknowledges the Traditional Custodians of the
land on which we live and work.
We honour the ancestors and the Elders past and present and
emerging, we extend that respect to all Aboriginal people, who
continue to care for Country.
We recognise that our National Office is located on Gadigal
Land of the people of the Eora Nation.
WMRR recognises Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples'
spiritual and cultural connection and inherent right to protect
the land, waters, sky and natural resources of Australia.
This connection goes deep and has since the Dreaming.
2

WMRR
STRUCTURE
WMRR has a governance Board of Directors, which consists
of directly elected members, peak members and skilled
directors. Our members actively participate in state
branches and working groups at the national, state, and
specific industry sector level, which coupled with WMRR’s
Strategic Plan 2023-2026 informs our policy and advocacy
BOARD OF
efforts on behalf of industry.
DIRECTORS

Six (6) Board meetings;
Five (5) national divisions that held 28 meetings;
CEO and
Six (6) state branch committees that held 59 meetings;
NATIONAL
and
OFFICE 25 state-based working groups that held approximately
78 meetings.
A total of 1571 members participated in these meetings in 2024.
WMRR also has a professional CEO led office that supports
the activities of the Association and industry.

Waste Management and Resource Recovery Association
MEMBER
INFORMATION
MEMBER
COMMUNICATIONS
In addition to communications issued through our Branches,
Divisions and Working Groups, Association members are
kept up to date and informed of industry and Association
news through WMRR’s regular electronic correspondence,
including:
Weekly Resource Bulletins that provide a
comprehensive round-up of weekly policy and
regulatory changes, grants, commercial, and funding
announcements, industry and government reports, and
current consultations from around Australia;
Specific issue updates as required;
Monthly Wrap-Up which showcases the Association’s
activities, media releases, a snapshot of our CEO’s
appearances in mainstream and trade media, WMRR’s
policy submissions for the month as well as a forthcoming
events and conferences. WMRR CEO’s bi-monthly Inside
Waste CEO column and National President’s Board
communiqué are also featured in these.

2024 Annual Report
NATIONAL CONFERENCES
2024 ENVIRO CONFERENCE
Our national circular economy conference was held in Brisbane
at the end of June attracting 160 delegates. Across two (2)
days, delegates explored and discussed the systems thinking
required to reduce the demand for raw materials, think
differently about design, and encourage reuse and repair
through responsible production and consumption.
2024 AUSTRALIAN RESOURCE
RECOVERY CONFERENCE
Around 200 delegates participated in WMRR’s inaugural
Australian Resource Recovery Conference. Operators,
practitioners, policymakers, regulators, and product
developers from across the country discussed all aspects of
recovering material, making products, and keeping them
circulating for as long as possible, including its clear role in
addressing both emissions and biodiversity loss.
2024 waste and resource recovery
conference (WMRR SUPPORTED)
This annual conference (formerly known as the Waste and
Recycle Conference) is hosted by the Waste Management and
Resource Recovery Association of Australia (WMRR),
Department of Water and Environmental Regulation (DWER),
and Western Australian Local Government Association
(WALGA), is still the leading waste and resource recovery event
in Western Australia. In 2024, over 414 delegates attended.

2024 Annual Report
BIOHAZARD WASTE
INDUSTRY
Modernizing tracking systems, updating clinical waste
guidelines, and enhancing national coordination
continued to be the key issues discussed by the Biohazard
Waste Division in 2024.
Much of the conversation focused on the NSW EPA and
Queensland’s Department of Environment, Science and
Innovation (DESI) collaboration with KPMG to roll out a new
Integrated Waste Tracking System (IWTS) to replace the
outdated online tracking platforms and modernize and
improve transparency in hazardous waste tracking.
Queensland also updated its "Guideline: Clinical and Related
Waste" in February 2024 emphasising proper segregation,
storage, transportation, and disposal of clinical waste.
However, questions remain about the volume and type of data
regulators should collect through IWTS. Stakeholders suggest a
focus on outcomes like origin, transporter, and disposal, rather
than real-time tracking, which is often impractical.
Unfortunately progress on the IWTS system has halted in
Queensland, with some stakeholders, including waste
companies and the broader industry, raising concerns about
the administrative burden involved in such a system.
However, there is genuine interest from industry and
regulators in harmonising data collection approaches
nationally with a connected, streamlined system that
balances effective oversight with practicality, avoiding the
need for redundant data entry or collection. We look
forward to progressing this further in 2025.
The impact of single use plastic regulations is also starting to
materialise in the sector, noting that many of these provide
exemptions for specific medical and scientific applications where
no practical alternatives exist. This area will be a watching brief
for industry to see if such alternatives come to market.
I would like to thank our committed BWI Division members
for their contributions in 2024 and look forward to
continuing collaborating with the Division in 2025.
gAYLE SLOAN
CEO WMRR

DIVISON CHAIR
Queensland consulted on a proposed revision to its
guidelines but paused this process. NSW is likely to release
an updated guideline for consultation in the near term.
WMRR members have been active across the board forming
or maintaining working groups with EPAs forming to discuss
some uncertainties and inconsistencies within license
conditions, guidance and expectations to flag concerns and
improve outcomes.
Operational Purpose Deductions (OPDs) and Levy Issues
continue to be on the agenda, with inconsistencies in the
application of OPDs. NSW, SA, and Tasmania have been
particularly active in discussions around levy exemptions
and OPD frameworks, which we appreciate may be linked to
regulation and require review in line with state Waste Levy
reviews in the new year.
Emerging monitoring technologies like “drones” and
land/air/satellite methane sensors are now being evaluated
and in some cases being used by regulators. Technological
improvements over the last 20 years are likely to see
changes in guidance and the tools available to operators to
measure methane abatement and monitor site emissions
and move beyond the NGERS Method.

2024 Annual Report
NATIONAL WASTE
EDUCATORS
Waste Education in 2024:
A Year of Growth and Engagement Looking Ahead
This year has been significant for waste education within With a strong foundation built in 2024, we anticipate
WMRR, with key developments, new initiatives, and further growth, innovation, and collaboration in waste
strengthened collaboration across the sector. education in 2025. We remain committed to supporting
educators, enhancing engagement, and driving meaningful
At the start of the year, we conducted a national survey for change in waste avoidance, resource recovery, and circular
waste educators to better understand priorities and areas of economy initiatives.
interest. The results highlighted strong engagement with
Behaviour Change Theory, particularly in Reuse and Repair
and Food and Garden Waste. Educators also expressed a
desire for more workshops and interactive learning
opportunities, which we are actively working to expand.
Across Australia, several states have made progress in rolling
out Food Organic and Green Organic (FOGO) green bins and
kitchen caddies to support organics recovery. The WMRR
network has played a key role in assisting with public
messaging and education during these rollouts, and this
support will continue into 2025.
A major milestone in 2024 was the revival of the Victorian
Waste Educators Group. This group has been highly active,
grace barilla
hosting a range of presentations from industry leaders,
DIVISON CHAIR
including:
Sustainability Victoria – Small Changes, Big Impacts
EnviroCom – Kerbside Bin Audits and the Value of
Conversation
Tomra Cleanaway – Introducing the Container Deposit
Scheme
We thank the Victorian team for their leadership and
commitment to waste education.
National Campaigns and Industry
Collaboration
A major highlight of the year was the launch of The Great
Unwaste, a national food waste avoidance campaign aimed
at reducing food waste by over 20% by 2030. This initiative
aligns with national waste reduction targets and will remain
a key focus area in the coming years.
WMRR also facilitated an extensive series of webinars and
events over the past 12 months, covering a diverse range of
topics, including:
Creating Clothing Circularity by 2030
Packaging Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) Schemes
An Introduction to Biochar
A Snapshot on Tyres
Fighting Household Food Waste
Activating Design for a Circular Economy
These events have provided valuable learning and networking
opportunities for waste educators, reinforcing the importance
of continued knowledge-sharing within the sector.

2024 Annual Report
SOUTH AUSTRALIA AND
NORTHERN TERRITORY
STATE BRANCH
In 2024, the WARR industry acted on increasing concerns about
battery disposal (or rather the lack of safe disposal options),
enhancing market demand for recovered products, the next
tranche of single use plastic bans, wastes collections policy,
export bans, container deposit scheme reform, and the early
development of new SA waste strategy, waste and resource
recovery legislation and planning policies.
Green Industries SA (GISA) continued to invest for a more
circular economy. GISA’s work included supporting various
sustainability guides, a waste textile collection and the new
Saveful app for food waste avoidance. GISA continued to
expand the Circular Procurement Knowledge Hub. The fourth
tranche of single use plastic bans took effect on 1 September
2024, applying, with some exemptions, to barrier bags, thick
shopping bags, beverage containers, expanded polystyrene food
and beverage containers and trays, confetti, balloon sticks and
food bag tags. Following on from its efforts in 2023, GISA had a
continuing focus on the clean-up from the massive flooding in
late 2022 along River Murray communities.
The EPA continued early engagement activities for the review of
the Environment Protection (Waste to Resources) Policy (W2R
EPP), culminating in a formal consultation paper. The EPA also
consulted on draft container deposit scheme amendments and
held early engagement towards new climate change policy. The
State Government implemented an engineered stone ban.
WMRR representatives presented to the Select Committee
conducting a Parliamentary Inquiry into Soft Plastics and met with
the Minister for Climate, Environment and Water regarding a
proposed kerbside collection laws and battery management. In
response, the Minister convened a stakeholder roundtable on
batteries in August and a free drop off event for embedded
batteries was coordinated by GISA in October 2024.
The South Australian (SA) Branch met eleven times across the
year as well as convening additional subgroup discussions.
Through this, WMRR has helped guide understanding of key
issues across the WARR industry, including receiving a mix of
presentations, highlighting areas for regulatory reform and
identifying upcoming opportunities.
WMRR made submissions on SA proposals relating to single
use plastic amendment regulations, draft container deposit
scheme amendment bill, draft Greater Adelaide Regional
Plan, draft State Infrastructure Strategy and the W2R EPP.
In addition, WMRR SA members’ participation across 2024
saw a continued focus on building market demand through
the Sustainable Procurement Working Group and
promoting a circular economy and key WARR sector needs
through the W2R EPP Review Reference Group and draft
Waste Strategy discussions.

Waste Management and Resource Recovery Association
The Women of WARR Leadership Breakfast was held in March
2024 and an SA update for WMRR members on the release of
GISA’s Circular Economy Resource Recovery report, Kerbside Data
reports and EPA’s Environment Protection (Waste to Resources)
Policy review was held in September 2024. A highlight for the
Branch was contributing to the success of the inaugural Australian
Resource Recovery Conference in October 2024. The Young
Professionals and friends enjoyed informal drinks regularly,
including opportunities to network with more senior members.
The year wrapped up with another fantastic SA Golf Day and well-
attended informal SA Branch drinks in late November following
consecutive working group and Committee meetings.
Working groups
SA retained four (4) active working groups - Waste
Educators, RRMD, Young Professionals and Landfill - as well
as actively participating in various national Divisions. I would
like to take this opportunity to acknowledge the
commitment of our working group officer bearers
throughout the year – Grace Barila supported by Cameron
O’Malley (Waste Educators), Leah Maxwell supported by
Marina Wagner (RRMD), Amy Henshaw supported by
Kristian Le Gallou (Young Professionals) and Don Richardson
(Landfill). In September 2024, Cameron O’Malley became
Waste Education Group Chair and Alison Hackett-Rogers
became Vice-Chair. Kristian Le Gallou became President of
the Young Professionals and Maria Madsen became Vice-
Chair. The efforts of the previous and incoming chairs, active
members, presenters and tour hosts for continuing group
success is warmly commended.
The groups held a range of meetings, including
presentations on behaviour change, waste education,
PVC recycling, linen recycling, procurement, engineered
stone, solar panel recycling, reducing food waste,
recycling clothing, the World Circular Economy Forum
and single use plastic recycling. The Young Professionals
had site tours to ResourceCo’s Alternative Fuels and
Glass Crushing facilities, BioBag’s manufacturing facility
and AdBri Birkenhead while the Educators had a tour of
IWS Wingfield and Dublin EcoHub.
The Branch Committee and Working Groups continued to be
well supported by our Branch Support Officer, Brian
Johnston. His efforts to help our work and achievements are
greatly appreciated.

Waste Management and Resource Recovery Association
There was some amazing WMRR events held in WA during
the year. The Woman in Waste Breakfast, was a highlight
where we heard from some power houses of the WA waste
industry, including Elizabeth Carr, Janelle Ostenson and
Libby Eustance.
The WA WMRR Resource Recovery Conference was held in
September where we asked, “How do we get to 80%
resource recovery by 2030”? Conference highlights included
the presentation from End Food Waste Australia – (Ella
Winnall and Mandy Hall), an inspirational and practical
initiative to end food waste. We will watch with interest as
the “Great Unwaste” gets traction in 2025.
Thanks to our working groups who continue year on year to
support the branch with dedication and commitment –
circular economy (chaired by Haley Rolfe with Monika Kern
as Vice-Chair), landfill (chaired by Chris Stannard), and
Waste Educators (chaired by Emily Tomsett).
2025 is a pivotal year for the WARR industry in WA. With the
updated waste strategy, resource recovery legislation and a
re-elected government, the challenges & opportunities for
the sub-branch are ever evolving. Finally, thanks to Libby
Eustance (Vice President) for her support this year and to all
members who contribute to the sub-branch.
JASON PUGH
WESTERN AUSTRALIA
BRANCH PRESIDENT

Waste Management and Resource Recovery Association
BOARD COMMITTEE
REPORTS
1. AUDIT AND RISK
The WMRR Board is supported
by three (3) committees:
The Audit and Risk Committee (ARC) is a sub-committee
within the national board of the Waste Management and
Resource Recovery Association of Australia (the
Association). The ARC monitors the integrity of financial
statements and assists in approving external auditing
policies and procedures. It also considers the ongoing
assessment of current and emerging risks in the
Association’s operations.
The key objectives of the Committee are to:
Approve the terms of engagement for the audit officer
and scope,
Monitor the integrity of financial statements, and
Review the Association’s arrangements.
The ARC is composed of Phil Carbins, Michelle Mandl, Gayle
Sloan, and Isabel Axiö (Chair), supported by Lisa Lepore.
Since July 2023, the committee has:
Reviewed the items and weighting of the registered
risks, making minor updates for WMRR, which were
approved by the board.
Discussed and reviewed the proposed 2025 budget,
sought clarification on figure comparisons with previous
years and a few line items. The ARC sought and gained
approval for the budget from the board.
The ARC is satisfied that the Association is managing
operational risk and its finances with awareness, care, and
diligence. As the WARR sector grows, the Association
remains fiercely relevant in an increasingly competitive
space. This is demonstrated by sustained growth in
memberships, attendance at events, and engagement
from governments.
There was a marginal loss recorded for the 2024 calendar
year due to increased cost of event delivery, travel and
general operation, as well as lower-than-expected revenue
from exhibitors and sponsors. However, this was also a year
in which the Association responded to industry issues and
invested in two key studies—Phytocap and PFAS levels in
land-applied organics.
With the review of the 2024 profit and loss statement, the
conservative approach of the 2025 budget built from first
principles, and the ongoing monitoring of risk and
arrangements, the ARC considers the Association to be in a
stable financial position, with proactive controls in place to
manage it on behalf of its members.
ISABEL AXiö
Audit and Risk Committee Chair
